title: Panchayati Raj and Local Governance in India

information.title: Definition
information.description: Panchayati Raj is a system of local self-governance in India, particularly in rural areas. It aims to ensure greater participation of people in local governance and more effective implementation of rural development programmes.

information.title: Constitutional Basis
information.description: The 73rd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992, gave constitutional status to Panchayati Raj institutions. It added Part IX to the Constitution, titled 'The Panchayats'.

information.title: Three-Tier System
information.description: Panchayati Raj typically has a three-tier structure: Gram Panchayat at the village level, Panchayat Samiti at the block level, and Zila Parishad at the district level.

information.title: Urban Local Bodies
information.description: The 74th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1992, provides for urban local bodies. These include Municipal Corporations, Municipal Councils, and Nagar Panchayats, depending on the size of the urban area.

information.title: Elections and Reservations
information.description: Regular elections to local bodies are mandated. One-third of the seats (including those for chairpersons) are reserved for women. Reservations are also provided for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

information.title: Functions
information.description: Local bodies are responsible for various functions including sanitation, public health, street lighting, and maintenance of community assets. The specific functions can vary by state.

quizQuestions.question: What is the main aim of the Panchayati Raj system?
options: To ensure greater participation of people in local governance
To reduce the power of state governments
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: To ensure greater participation of people in local governance
